Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond the validity of his visa; filed a pending humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application based on marriage to a Canadian citizen and risk of harm if returned to Iran.

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Removal officer's decision to proceed with deportation despite a pending H&C application

Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending H&C application outcome

Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) Removal Officer

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's determination that adequate state protection exists in Colombia is reasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board considered both favorable and conflicting evidence regarding state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to demonstrate inability or unwillingness to avail themselves of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' actions were found inconsistent with genuine fear; lack of reporting to authorities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – reasonableness standard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by FARC and insufficient state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to adequate state protection despite imperfections

Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court upheld the Board's decision

Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted threats from organized armed group
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of state protection programs in urban areas like Bogota
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Ongoing human rights violations by FARC but declining state control
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – involving death threats and forced recruitment
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: General risk in rural areas, lower in urban centers with state presence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on refusal to comply with demands
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish lack of state protection due to unreported incidents
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to inconsistencies and failure to seek asylum elsewhere
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants’ fear deemed not subjectively genuine
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – Convention refugee criteria

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA requires both subjective and objective components

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate personal risk upon return

Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal risk upon return; rebuttal of state protection presumption
Decision_Rationale: RPD concluded El Salvador provides adequate state protection based on recent anti-gang efforts; applicant failed to rebut state protection with clear evidence

Violation_Type: Failure to appear at scheduled hearing

Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Legal_Issue: Whether the Director General breached the duty of fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to objections
Evidence_Assessment: Failure to provide opportunity to respond to objections prior to decision
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness may require providing parties an opportunity to address objections in administrative processes
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter or correctness, depending on context
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of objections and lack of response opportunity
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of natural justice
Defendant_Response: Director General proceeded with decision without addressing applicant's right to reply
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision via certiorari, costs
Outcome: Decision quashed, costs awarded to applicant, no referral back under s. 18

Application_Facts: Ms. Roohi scored 67 points but was rejected due to limited English skills and teaching experience, deemed insufficient for economic establishment in Canada.
Evidence_Used: Assessment of English language proficiency, teaching experience, and economic establishment potential
Decision_Outcome: Application refused based on negative substituted evaluation
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the visa officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably determined that awarded points did not reflect applicant's ability to become economically established in Canada

Dispute_Type: Jurisdictional dispute in patent infringement case
Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, has jurisdiction to hear a patent infringement case against the Province of Ontario
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike granted; Federal Court lacks jurisdiction
Legal_Rule: Section 5 of the Proceedings Against the Crown Act (Ont.) allows tort actions against the provincial Crown but confines them to Ontario courts
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement by the Province of Ontario
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on jurisdictional grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Relevant statutes and case law regarding jurisdiction
Legal_Framework: Provincial and federal legislative framework governing suits against the Crown
Defendant_Response: Ontario moved to strike the action due to lack of jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Adjudication of patent infringement in Federal Court
Outcome: Action struck out; plaintiffs cannot sue Ontario in the Federal Court
Legal_Provision: Section 5, Proceedings Against the Crown Act (Ont.)
Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Violation_Type: Claiming refugee status without sufficient evidence of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution for attending an unregistered church in China; RPD found oral evidence not credible and no documented incidents of persecution in Guangdong Province
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation or exaggeration of persecution risk
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision on credibility and evidence assessment
Evidence_Used: Oral testimony, documentary evidence regarding religious persecution in China
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documented incidents of persecution in Guangdong; insufficient corroboration of personal claims
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's oral evidence not credible
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Relief_Sought: Overturning of RPD's negative decision on refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on religion under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: Conclusion that there was no serious possibility of persecution was within the range of acceptable outcomes

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether permanent residence can be granted on humanitarian and compassionate grounds despite past misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s.25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s.117(9)(d)
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sponsor previously misrepresented marital status in 1992
Crimes.Evidence_Type: CAIPS notes, family dependency records, child's best interests
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of the child, family unity, long-term residency of sponsor
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess H&C factors adequately
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision under administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Family dependency, financial support, impact on child
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s.25(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Misrepresentation affecting eligibility under family class
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation of marital status in 1992 application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether H&C grounds were properly considered in denial of permanent residence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sponsor failed to declare dependents in 1992 application
Crimes.Evidence_Type: CAIPS notes, evidence of family relationships and financial support
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to family circumstances
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of the child, ongoing family ties in Canada
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of visa officer decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of family integration, financial dependency, child’s well-being
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s.25(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Past misrepresentation affecting current sponsorship eligibility
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Omission of dependent children in prior immigration application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with voluntary departure orders
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visitor status, applied for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds, had minor child Min Ji under 18 at time of application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants without valid status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and failed to depart voluntarily
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Inadequate consideration of H&C factors, particularly best interests of the child
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Establishment in Canada, family ties, children’s integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer underestimated hardships and dismissed establishment in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and re-assessment of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to properly assess best interests of Min Ji rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of humanitarian and compassionate application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness and incorrect application of H&C tests, including best interests of the child
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case returned for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not found to be an issue
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residential history, employment records, children’s education in Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to long-term residence and family establishment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of minor child Min Ji
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to adequately analyze best interests of the child and disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under s. 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Extent of applicants’ establishment in Canada and impact on children
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to officer’s decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long-term illegal stay since 2001, unauthorized work, integration of children

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered as visitors, remained since 2001, established lives, applied for permanent residence on H&C grounds
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visas and remained without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient analysis of best interests of Min Ji, who was under 18 at time of application
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, community ties, children’s education and integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer inadequately assessed hardships and best interests of the child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and re-determination with proper H&C assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable failure to consider Min Ji's best interests

Crimes.Application_Facts: Jin was absent from Canada for 1,118 days; claimed full-time employment abroad with J Brother and Dragon Mart but provided insufficient proof of remuneration and inconsistent documentation.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 730-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues due to inconsistent testimonies and lack of verifiable employment records
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal dismissed by IAD; judicial review sought and dismissed by Federal Court
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian immigration authorities' jurisdiction over permanent resident obligations
Evidence_Used: Business documents from J Brother and Dragon Mart
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of remuneration, inconsistent employment records, insufficient documentation of full-time status
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD found Jin's evidence not credible due to inconsistencies and gaps in documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; removal order upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on full-time employment exception and humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Jin failed to demonstrate full-time employment by a Canadian business abroad and lacked strong humanitarian and compassionate grounds due to prolonged absence and weak ties to Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency obligation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Full-time employment abroad by a Canadian business and humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, administrative law principles
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld by Federal Court
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Removal order issued and appeal dismissed
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent Resident claiming exemption from residency requirement
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Not applicable – case focused on immigration compliance, not persecution
Crimes.Credibility: Assessed as low due to inconsistent testimony and lack of supporting documentation
